Although he has a good group of livestock, he now wants to buy one more milk cow. As such, Bahodir is seeking a business development loan through KIVA in the amount of 3,200 STJ ($950) over 4 months to purchase such a cow.

loans.use: To expand and improve his livestock business by purchasing another milk cow

loans.name: Ni Wayan Murdani

texts.id:
Ni Wayan Murdani sudah menyelesaikan pinjamannya tahap pertama. Pada pinjaman pertama Ni Wayan Murdani memelihara 4 ekor babi penggemukan yang dipelihara selama 5 bulan. Hasil penjualan 4 ekor babi adalah 4 * Rp. 1.300.000.- = Rp. 5.200.000.- Pakan yang dihabiskan oleh 4 ekor babi selama 5 bulan adalah  4 * Rp. 750.000.- = Rp. 3.000.000.- Harga anak babi saat beli Rp. 250.000.- * 4 = Rp. 1.000.000.- Jadi selama 5 bulan pemeliharaan, Ni Wayan Murdani memperoleh keuntungan Rp. 1.000.000.-
Untuk pinjaman kedua difokuskan untuk pembelian pakan karena harga pakan babi saat ini sangat tinggi. Dengan induk yang dimilikinya saat ini, Ni wayan Murdani tidak khawatir dalam pengadaan anak babi.
texts.en:
Ni Wayan Murdani is a debtor of DINARI Foundation, and has paid her first loan. With the first loan, she was able to raise 4 piglets, and within 5 months, she could sell them for Rp 1,300,000 each, and earned a total of Rp 5,200,000. She bought the piglets for Rp 250,000 each. To raise the piglets, she spent Rp 750,000 a month to purchase fodder, and spent Rp 3,000,000 in total. So in 5 months, Ni Wayan Murdani was able to earn Rp 1,000,000 income. The next loan will be used to purchase fodder which is now getting more expensive. For Ni Wayan Murdani has had a pig mother, she does not have to worry about how to get piglets.

Translated from Indonesian by Hestyana Dyah Kuntari, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Memelihara penggemukan

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Catalina, a member of the Dos Mil (“Two Thousand”) Village Bank, is 64 years old and married with eight children. Leaving on Mondays and returning on Thursdays, Catalina travels to the Carhuanca market once a week to sell vegetables, bread and hardware items and to buy leather, cochinilla (a local cactus used to make cosmetics) and tara tree pods (used to tan leather) to bring back to Ayacucho to sell.

She is now requesting a loan to buy door lock mechanisms and padlocks, which she will sell at the Carhuanca market. Catalina’s dream is to improve her business. Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

loans.use: To buy door locks and padlocks.

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Hoàng Thị Chính  năm nay 32 tuổi, gia đình chị  có 2 con đang tuổi đến trường.  Hiện tại chị làm công việc chăn nuôi còn chồng chị đi buôn bán chiếu. Với thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng  gia đình chị đang ngày càng có điều kiện hơn để đầu tư cho các con ăn học và cải thiện cuộc sống
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được  vay 5.000.000đ để đầu tư cho công việc kinh daonh chiếu của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Hoàng Thị Chính is 32 years old. She has two children who attend school. At present, she works raising animals and her husband runs a business selling bamboo mats. With their total income of 3,000,000 VND (180 USD) per month, the family is gradually able to invest more in the children’s education and improve their standard of living. In the next lending cycle, she hopes to borrow 5,000,000 VND (300 USD) to invest in the family’s bamboo mat business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bamboo mats

loans.name: Mujeres Pensando En El Futuro Group

texts.en:
Ana R. R. is a coordinator for the group Mujeres Pensando en el Futuro (Women Thinking of the Future).  Her group has five members.  Ana is 58 years old, and her husband is 56 years old.  They do not have any children together, but she is the mother of two, and he is a father of three.  All of the children are adults.

Ana has a small cafeteria.  In the cafeteria, it is possibly to buy coffee and drinks, such as orange juice and soft drinks.  She also sells snacks.  Ana is about to receive her second loan.

The first loan made it possibly for her to expand her business.  With her new loan, she hopes and believes she can increase her business even more.  She has two dreams.  The first dream is that she one day will be able to buy a nice house.  The second dream is to travel as a tourist to the USA and Mexico.

loans.use: Increase product availability in business

loans.name: Trabajando Para El Futuro Group

texts.en:
"Trabajando para el futuro" or "Working for the future" is a large group of 20 hopeful people trying to receive a loan. This group is a great example of the power of micro-credit, and the effects it can have on the poor. This group is all hoping to receive their 6th or 7th loans. All the previous loans have all been paid back in full and on time, and now they hope to receive an even larger loan. This group of 20 hardworking people have all started to realize that they have the ability to change their future, and have all started to experience some success. Receiving a 7th loan is not something that all borrowers end up getting to, and that is in it self a great testament to the character and hard work of this group.

Ynes J. is the group representative, and a perfect example to represent this group. Ynes is a very outgoing, hardworking mother to 3 children. She is an extremely loving mother and has done everything in her power to proviD. her children with everything she never had. Ynes has lived in extreme poverty her whole life, and decided a few years back that she wanted to change her future and the future of her family. She received her first loan from Esperanza International and started a small salon from her house. From there she kept working hard and kept increasing the services and products of her salon, and today she has a very successful business. She can finally afford to pay for all of life's basic necessities, and even some luxuries. She has never been happier than she is now, and feels like she can beat poverty. The best part is that she is a testament to her children that they don't have to accept poverty as part of their lives, and can create a better life. Ynes is very excited about the future and is happy with the changes SHE maD. in her life! She is on the right path, and ready to keep increasing her business.

Thank you for your support of Ynes, and the group.

loans.use: Buy products for her beauty salon

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es:
Isabel es socia del Banco Comunal Las Hormigas.
Isabel es separada, tiene 40 años y 5 hijos, Isabel es vende frutas variadas de manera ambulatoria cerca al cementerio de la ciudad, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda de su hijo.
Isabel necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de frutas variadas.
Los sueños de Isabel son construir su casa y que sus hijos culminen sus estudios.
texts.en:
Isabel is a member of the Las Hormigas ("The Ants") Community Bank. Isabel is separated, is 40 years old and has five children. Isabel sells various fruit on foot near the city cemetary, an activity that she performs every day with the help of her son. Isabel needs a loan of 1,200 soles which will be invested in the purchase of various fruit. Isabel's dreams are to build a house and that her children finish their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of various fruit.

loans.name: Nazario

texts.es: Nazario está a punto de cumplir 30 años, es soltero, aun vive en la casa de su madre en compañía de su hermana. Todos sus hermanos se fueron a Lima en busca de un mejor porvenir, y le han propuesto irse con ellos, pero él prefiere apostar por el arte de labrar la tierra, como él llama a la agricultura, ya que le gusta mucho esta actividad. Años atrás solo sembraba en chacras temporales (regadas por la lluvia), y sus cosechas eran en los meses abril a mayo. Pero quiso cambiar esa realidad alquilando chacras de regadío y cambiado todas las semillas de acuerdo al tipo de tierra. Han pasado más de tres años y por fin está viendo los frutos de su esfuerzo. Ahora sus cosechas son  cada dos o tres veces por año, y cree haber aprendido las técnicas para convertirse en un gran agricultor. Sus metas próximas son de sembrar en la costa, debido a que cuenta con una buena cantidad de semillas especiales para ese clima, así incrementará su producción, con ello sus ganancias y convertirá su labor en una actividad muy rentable. Hace un año Nazario fue el presidente de su banco comunal, y cumplió muy bien con sus funciones, este es su 8vo préstamo con MFP, en todo este tiempo demostró responsabilidad en sus pagos. El dinero que está solicitando es para la compra de fertilizantes químicos, para sus nuevas siembras en chacras costeñas.
texts.en:
Nazario is about to turn 30, he is single, and still lives in his mother's house along with his sister. His other siblings all left for Lima to look for a better future, and have proposed that he go with them, but he prefers to stay and work the land, as he refers to agriculture, since he really likes this activity. Many years ago he only farmed small plots of land (watered by the rain), and his harvests were in the months of April and May. But he wanted a change from renting land and changed all the seeds according to the type of land. More than three years have passed and he is finally seeing the fruit of his labor. Now his crops are harvested two or three times a year, and he believes he has learned the techniques to become a great farmer. His upcoming goals are to farm on the coast, since he has a large quantity of seeds especially for that climate. In this way he will increase his production which will increase his earnings and make his work a very profitable activity. Last year Nazario was the president of his community bank, and he completed all his tasks very well. This is his eighth loan with MFP and in all this time he has shown responsibility in his payments. The money he is asking for is for buying chemical fertilizers for planting his new coastal crops.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Vun

texts.en:
Mrs. Vun H., 55, and her husband, Mr. Den Yem, 57, live on an Island in Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1970 and have three children: one son who is in grade 10 and two daughters who are silk weavers.

Vun use to be a silk weaver, but she stopped weaving and gave her looms to her daughters. They sell their finished products to a middleman who then sells them in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a farmer; besides farming he raises cows as well. Vun is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to add to her own money to purchase oxen for her husband to raise.

loans.use: To add in her own money to purchase oxen for husband to raise.

loans.name: Adnan

texts.en:
Adnan is a 36 year old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with his wife and their five children. Adnan has been selling aluminum. He also produces doors and windows. He requested a loan of US $2000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase electrical tools for his work. This is the first time that Adnan has requested a loan.

Adnan is special in his work because he does it well. His clients are his friends, neighbors and people from his region. When he first started his business, he had difficulty building a network. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To buy power tools

loans.name: Ana Isaura

texts.es:
En el municipio de Chichigalpa, la señora Ana M. se dedica arduamente a atender su negocio de pulpería el cual posee en su casa de habitación donde desde hace 12 años se dedica con gran ahínco a vender los diferentes productos ofreciéndolos a sus clientes.

Hoy en día ella ha acudido a Ceprodel con el propósito de obtener un crédito para la compra de los productos ya que le es de importancia obtenerlos y de esta manera salir adelante en su negocio que tanto requiere de su apoyo en este momento para salir adelante.
texts.en:
In the town of Chichigalpa, Señora Ana M. arduously devotes herself to the grocery business she runs in her home. For 12 years, she has devoted herself with great determination to the sale of the various products she offers to her customers.

Currently, Sra. M. has come to Ceprodel to request a loan for the purchase of inventory it is important for her to obtain. In this way, she will progress in her business, where this assistance is now needed in order to proceed.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase inventory

loans.name: Sairiniso

texts.en:
Since 1992, Sairiniso, a loving grandmother of three grandchildren, has dedicated herself to processing granulated sugar and then making from it a variety of pastries to sell in local markets. She begins her workday at early morning along with her daughter-in-law, who is also engaged in this business. Sairiniso’s dreams is to grow her business so she can offer her products personally in markets throughout the regions of her country, thereby earning greater income. For this reason, she is requesting a loan of 5000 Somoni to expand her business by purchasing additional equipment for processing granulated sugar. Let’s get behind this dedicated mother to help her keep making progress in her business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes: its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment, forcing hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new equipment for processing granulated sugar.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.es:
Sandra es socia del Banco Comunal Violeta.
Sandra es soltera, tiene 21 años y 1 hijo, Sandra vende golosinas y canchas de manera ambulatoria en el parque de la ciudad de Ayacucho, Además Sandra trabaja en un restaurante como ayudante.
Sandra necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de golosinas.
Sandra sueña con construir su casa y mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Sandra is a member of the Violeta Microfinance Institute.

Sandra is a 21-year-old single mother with 1 son. She sells candy and popcorn as a street vendor at the Ayacucho city park. Additionally, Sandra works as an assistant at a restaurant.

She needs a 600.00 PEN loan, which will be invested in purchasing candy.

Sandra dreams of having her own house built and of improving her business.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase candy

loans.name: Tehran

texts.en:
Tehran M. is married with three children. He has always been a hard-working man who has made sure, from a young age, that his family never goes without their daily bread.

Tehran has a grocery store where he sells different kinds of foodstuffs. He began this enterprise eight years ago with a starting capital of $200. Thanks to his perseverance and dedication, he has expanded his business over time.  It has become a family affair now, as they help him with the business. 

Today, Tehran needs to buy additional foodstuffs to increase the range of his goods. For this purpose, he is requesting a loan of $2000. He is ready to work even harder, to make sacrifices, and to make extra effort to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur.

loans.use: To purchase more food products

loans.name: Julia Herminia

texts.es:
Julia  es socia del Bancomunal  San Luís. 
Julia es casada tiene 7 hijos el ultimo tiene 12 años que esta estudiando en al escuela estatal.
Julia trabaja desde los  16 años, donde trabajaba  la señora  se dedicaba hacer pasteles y ella aprendió,  la señora se murió, Julia se quedo  sin trabajo, y se puso en su casa hacer pasteles ella los vende en los colegios, hospitales, los sábados y domingos limpia casas. 
Desde que Julia esta en Finca  su  capital ha crecido.
Julia necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles, para  la compra de harina, mantequilla, huevos. 
El sueño de Julia es trabajar  para comprase un carro para a ser movilidad escolar.
texts.en:
Julia is a member of Bancomunal San Luis. She is married and has seven children. Her youngest is 12 and goes to public school. Julia has been working since she was 16 years old. She learned to bake with the woman she used to work for, who baked cakes for a living. When the lady died Julia lost her job, so she started to bake cakes at home. She now sells them to schools and hospitals. She cleans houses on Saturday and Sunday. Julia’s financial resources have increased since she joined Finca. Julia has asked for a loan of 1,200 soles ($425). She will use the money to buy flour, butter and eggs. Her goal is to eventually buy a car to provide school transportation.

Translated from Spanish by Montserrat Zuckerman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy flour, butter and eggs

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian is a member of the Secondary borrower group in Ilala,Iringa,she is 33 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 1 child.Her child is aged 14 years.

lilian started her own clothing business selling clothes 3 years ago,she works 10 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Liliani`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania.She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more used clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Lilian hopes to save more money ans expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes

loans.name: Ifeoma

texts.en: Ifeoma sells clothes, shoes, bags and under wears in her shop. She is successful in her business because she is known for her good business and competitive prices. Ifeoma is 27 years old and married with a child. Ifeoma hopes for the loan amount of N50, 000 to purchase more clothes and under wears to sell. She is grateful to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and under wears to sell

loans.name: Maria Licet

texts.es: Doña Maria Licet Martínez Martínez posee un negocio de venta de mercadería en general desde hace 10 años, ella vende en los diferentes mercados y sus comarcas a precios favorables. Es madre de 3 hijos, los cuales son menores de edad, su esposo trabaja como conductor de camiones en Nicaragua y Centroamérica juntos tratan de motivarse para salir adelante y colaboran para que a sus hijos no les falte lo necesario. La señora Maria realiza sus compras de contado en el mercado de mangua porque es aquí donde sus productos son mucho más favorables, en donde y le generan un poco mas de ganancia todos los días se levanta con la esperanza de mejorar en su negocio y enseñarles a sus hijos a trabajar de manera muy humilde. Ella está solicitando un financiamiento para invertirlo en su negocio. su deseo es poner un negocio en su vivienda.
texts.en:
Doña Maria Licet Martínez Martínez has been selling general merchandise for the past 10 years. She offers her products at affordable prices throughout various markets in the region. She is the mother of three dependent children. Her husband is a truck driver who travels throughout Nicaragua and other parts of Central America. They both are motivated to move forward and work together so that their children lack nothing.

Sra. Maria buys her merchandise at the market in Managua because the products there are better. She hopes to earn a little more income every day, improve her business, and teach her children how to make an honest living. The loan she is requesting will be invested into her business. She hopes to be able to run her business out of her home.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Amanjol

texts.en:
Amanjol, 29, lives with his wife and two year old daughter in the Bayan-Ulgii province of western Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Amanjol is a very busy man, owning not just one but two businesses. He operates a shoe repairing business during the day and drives a taxi at night. Amanjol began repairing shoes in 2000 after he graduated high school. He was able to save up money for a car and begin his taxi service in 2006.

Today, his taxi service earns between 20,000 and 45,000 tugrugs (~14-31 USD) each day. Amanjol works many hours every day to provide his family the things they need. He would eventually like to hire an assistant in his shoe repair shop so he can grow his earning and expand his customer base. Until that time he will keep working hard and saving money for his family’s future.

Amanjol is requesting a 300,000 tugrug (~210 USD) loan to purchase more supplies like rubber, glue, leather and nails that he needs for his shoe repair business.

loans.use: Purchase raw material.

loans.name: Pearly

texts.en:
Pearly D. is from the village of Danlugan Lopez Jaena. She is 34 years old. Pearly is married. To make a living, Pearly owns & operates a sari-sari"  general store, selling a variety of products such as can goods, sugar, rice, salt, shampoo, soap and other products needed in the local community. Pearly has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Pearly joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pearly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. Pearly is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional product to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Pearly from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and to save the income for a future emergency. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units with offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional product to sell

loans.name: Francisca Zoila

texts.es:
La señora Francisca Zoila, pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Esperanza”, Distrito Juanjui, Provincia Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. Es soltera, tiene 46 años y 03 hijos, 02 que aun dependen de ella.

Lleva  24 años dedicándose a este tipo de actividad y fue por iniciativa propia quien decidió desarrollarse en este tipo de actividad y contando con un pequeño capital y el conocimiento en este tipo de actividad, no dudo en implementar su propio taller de costura, ubicada en su misma casa, un local muy bien acondicionado, para atender cordialmente a sus clientes que día a día, acuden a su taller para ser atendidos y es Francisca, quien  les espera  amablemente y con el carisma que siempre le ha caracterizado. 

En la actualidad, trabaja con pedidos de sus clientes anticipadamente, nos cuenta que le va muy bien. Una de sus metas por lograr es tener un taller  de alta costura e implementarlo con maquinas industriales modernas. Es ella quien personalmente les atiende  con la amabilidad y el carisma que le caracteriza. 

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500.00, comprará una maquina y una remalladora por que la que tiene ya no funciona bien, además si sobra el dinero comprará alfileres tijera y papel molde. 

Francisca, hoy en día se siente una mujer realizada, con  ganas de alcanzar y hacer realidad sus demás sueños. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudarla a iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarialmente.
texts.en:
Sra. Francisca Zoila is a member of the Hope Communal Bank, which is in the District of Juanjui, Mariscal Cáceres Province, Department of San Martín. She is 46 years old, single, and the mother of 3 children of whom 2 are still dependents.

Francisca has been engaged in sewing for 24 years. With the help of a little capital, she took the initiative to utilize her sewing skills by opening a dressmaking shop out of her house. Her business is well suited for welcoming customers, whom she greets with her friendly and charming personality.

Francisca informs us that her business is doing well. Her customers place their orders in advance. One of her goals is to open a boutique selling couture fashions and manufacture the garments using modern industrial equipment. With her loan of 1500 soles, she will purchase a sewing machine and an overlock stitcher because her current equipment is in disrepair. In addition, Francisca will use any leftover money to buy pins, scissors, and paper molds.

Today Francisca feels she is an accomplished woman and continues to strive for her other dreams. She thanks Manuela Ramos for helping her start her business and supporting many more women who want to grow as entrepreneurs.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sewing equipment & materials

loans.name: Mrs. Youren Say Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Sixteen people, who are all living in Prek Ta Ker village in Kandal province, make up this village bank loan. Each member will use the loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Youren S. is 28 years old and single and she is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates both rice and vegetables.

Mrs. Youren S. faces an obstacle with her plantation because she does not have enough money to grow rice on the field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy farming supplies for her plantation.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her farm

loans.name: Juliana

texts.es:
La señora Juliana es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Brisas del Río Blanco” del distrito D. Pilcuyo, provincia D. El Collao; ella tiene 40 años D. edad, está casada, tiene 03 hijos, los cuales viven con ella. Estudió secundaria incompleta. 
Juliana trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. hace 04 años; tiene diferentes negocios como: compra y venta D. productos D. la región, compra y venta D. prendas D. vestir y a la compra y venta D. queso(venD. en Arequipa e Ilave).
Nos cuenta que con su primer préstamo que fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, compró chuño, papas y queso, los que vendió en Arequipa.
Ella solicitará un préstamo D. S/. 3000.00 nuevos soles, los cuales invertirá en comprar un toro y el resto lo invertirá en la compra D. productos D. la región.
Su visión hacia el futuro es ser mayorista y tener un sitio fijo en Arequipa para poder vender sus productos.
Lo que mas le gusta D. su Banco Comunal es el préstamo con bajo interés y las charlas con las socias.
texts.en:
Juliana, 40, is a member of the “Las Brisas del Río Blanco” communal bank, which is located in Pilcuyo district, El Collao province. She is married and the mother of three children who are still dependent on her. She finished secondary school. Juliana has cooperated with the Manuela Ramos Movement for the last 4 years. She has different business activities like: buying and selling regional products, buying and selling clothing, and buying and selling cheese (she sells in Arequipa and Ilave). She tells us that her first loan was for 300 new soles. She bought chuño (freeze-dried potatoes), potatoes and cheese that she sold in Arequipa. She is requesting 3000 new soles to buy a bull; any remainder she will use to buy regional products. Her vision for the future is to be a wholesaler and have a fixed locale in Arequipa to sell her products. What she likes most about her communal bank is the low-interest loans and the talks with the members.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a bull.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy four calves to fatten and sell

loans.name: Monica Del Rocio

texts.es:
El banco comunal El Crédito es formado por un grupo de mujeres luchadoras que buscan cada día la manera de salir en adelante y así entregarles un mejor futuro a sus familias, viven por distintas partes de la ciudad de Cuenca, siendo esta la tercera ciudad mas importante del Ecuador, es una ciudad que tiene una belleza natural que enamora a propios y extraños.

La Sra. Mónica Jiménez es socia del banco comunal El Crédito,  vive en la urbe de la ciudad de Cuenca, tiene una amistad muy buena con todas sus compañeras del bankito, tiene 38 años de edad, vive en unión libre, fruto de esta unión han procreado 2 hijos que se encuentran de 20 y 15 años de edad, su  primera hija estudia en el colegio Ciudad de Cuenca, y su hijo menor en el colegio Octavio Cordero Palacios, su esposo es albañil, profesión que le permite aportar económicamente a su hogar, la casa en la que habitan es arrendada.

Mónica se dedica a la venta de encebollados (Sopa de pescado), tiene 5 años trabajando en este, su negocio está ubicado en su propia casa, su horario de trabajo es de 9 a.m. a 22 p.m., vendiendo su producto casi todos los días a excepción del día jueves que descansa para estar un poco mas con su familia, nos comenta que si le va muy bien en su negocio, aprendiendo esta labor por si sola ya que la necesidad y las ganas de superarse le dieron fuerzas para realizar este exquisito platillo, se encuentra en su segundo ciclo en la fundación y  fue una amiga la que la incentivo para formar parte de este grupo para que reciba los beneficios que la fundación entrega a todas sus socias, con el préstamo que la FUNDACION ESPOIR le hace entrega lo va a invertir en pagar unas deudas que adquirió. Las deudas que la Sra. Debe pagar son las que compra 80 libras semanales de pescado para la elaboración de sus encebollados y en el pago de sus joyas que se encuentran en prenda. Su gran sueño es llegar a tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
Community bank El Crédito is comprised of a group of determined women who aim, on a daily basis, to find ways in which to progress and create a better life for their families. The women live in different areas of the city of Cuenca, the third most important city in Ecuador. The city is surrounded by spectacular scenery that captivates visitors and residents alike. A member of the community bank El Crédito, Mrs. Monica J. lives in the city of Cuenca, and gets along with all her colleagues at the cooperative. She is 38 years old and lives with her common-law partner and two children, aged 20 and 15 years. Her eldest child (daughter) studies at the Ciudad de Cuenca college, and her son attends the Octavio Cordero Palacios school. Ms. J.’s partner is a builder whose work provides a steady income for the family. The family live in rented accommodation. Monica has been selling fish soup for the past five years. She does this from her house and works from 9am till 10pm every day except on Thursday, when she rests to spend time with her family. Monica taught herself how to run her business out of necessity and a wish to better herself, and reports that things are going well. This is Ms. J.’s second loan cycle as part of the Fundación after a friend encouraged her to form the collective and informed her about the benefits such a group could receive. Monica will use the loan provided by FUNDACION ESPOIR to repay some debts. The debts are for the 80 pounds of fish that she buys on credit each week for her fish soup, and to pay off some jewelery she had previously pawned. Her dream is to buy her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Justine Raymond, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay off debts from buying fish on credit, buy back jewelery from the pawn shop

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic A. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 27 years old. Marivic is single and has one infant child. To make a living, Marivic owns & operates a business selling electronic load (phone use cards) and some cell phone accessories. At the same time, Marivic has a small sari-sari store where she sells different goods in the local community. Marivic has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marivic joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marivic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marivic is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Marivic from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sol Naciente Group

texts.es:
Este comité  SOL NACIENTE se encuentra en pleno desarrollo con mucho trabajo para llevar a alcanzar los objetivos de manera integral para toadas, se encuentran en el décimo  ciclo
 dentro de la Fundacion Paraguaya cuenta con 19 integrantes.
Se pudo hablar con la  Sra . Delia Rolòn  posee un pequeño puesto de venta de frutas al costado del Supermercado Metro en la Avda Cacique Lambare de la ciudad de Asunción, ella va al mercado de abasto a comprar las frutas para elaborar su producto para la venta. Ella vende ademas jugos naturales, tiene clientela formadas con el ingreso que ella lo realiza dia a dia ayuda al marido para la alimentación de la familia..
Ademas ella posee un objetivo la de mejorar y ampliar su pequeño negocio para  ello piensa trabajar mucho con el comité y asi lograr su proposito..
A continuación se presentan las actividades aque se dedica cada integrante de los comit..
1
Ana Carolina A...
Vta de comestible.
2

9

Modista.
11

12

Venta de frutas
13

14

19

Vta de quiniela.
texts.en:
The committee “Sol Naciente” is just developing and still has much work to do to achieve its objectives in an integral way for everyone. It’s in its tenth cycle with Fundacion Paraguay and has 19 members. We were able to speak with Mrs. Delia Rolòn who has a small fruit stand next to the Metro Supermarket on Cacique Lambare Avenue in the city of Asunción. She goes to the wholesale market to buy fruits to sell. She also sells fresh fruit juices and has earned customers through her hard work. Her business helps her husband feed their family. She also would like to improve and grow her small business. To do this, she plans to spend a lot of time working with committee to achieve her goals. The following are the businesses that each of the committee’s member’s have: 1. Ana Carolina A... Sells groceries. 2. Emilce Aurora C.. Sells haberdasherly merceria 3. Maria Veronica P... Kiosk. 4. Basilia Ester A... Beauty Salon. 5. Elida R... Seamstress. 6.Carmen Anastacia M. Sells of cleaning products. 7. Zeneida R. V... Sells clothing. 8. Juana Bautista C... Sells sewing procucts. 9. Cecilia Raquel A... Sells clothing. 10. Maria Ruperta M... Seamstress. 11. Emilce Noemi V... Sells clothing. 12. Delia Rolon.. Sells fruits. 13. Cesilia E... Sells products for cleaning. 14. Lidia T.. Sells clothing. 15. Maria ErciliaO... Sells cosmetics. 16. Marlene Ramona C... Sells Avon products. 17. RuthMarlene R... Sells sewing products. 18. Maria Eugenia A... Sells food. 19. Eusebia I... Sells lotery tickets

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To puchase ingredients to make fook like:  meat, eggs, milk, condiments, and other things.

loans.name: Alla

texts.en:
Alla is married with two sons. She is a market entrepreneur from Mukachevo, Western Ukraine, where she sells women’s purses, backpacks, and bags in a marketplace next to the local bus station. Alla owns a well-equipped vending facility. She launched this business six years ago and currently has 30,000 Grivnyas invested in business.

Alla is hoping to use this loan for 6,500 Grivnyas to increase her assorted merchandise and grow her sales as a result. She believes financial assistance will help her keep her head over water in terms of the challenging economic recession. She is one of many small entrepreneurs who are struggling with staying afloat business-wise in Ukraine.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of women's bags.

loans.name: Norma Josefina

texts.es: La Sra Norma  es viuda con hijos mayores, domiciliado en la ciudad de Caacupe en el Barrio Virgen del Rosario, doña Norma posee una pequeña cantina en su domicilio y en la Escuela de su barrio donde diariamente atiende, solicita el apoyo de la Fundación Paraguaya y Kiva, para aumentar mas de mercaderías su negocios y satisfacer la demanda de sus clientelas y así obtener mas ingreso en su unidad familiar.
texts.en:
Norma is a widow and has five adult children. She lives in Caacupe's Virgen del Rosario neighborhood. She has a small eatery in her home and in the local neighborhood school. She tends to them daily. She is asking Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva for funding to increase stock items in her businesses so that she can meet customer demand and earn increased family income.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For food and snacks.

loans.name: Marietta

texts.en:
Marietta S. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 58 years old. Marietta is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Marietta runs a sari-sari (variety) store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Marietta has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $75 a month from these activities.

In 2010, Marietta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marietta is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Chicken and meat

loans.name: Alfonso

texts.es: El Sr. ALFONSO esta casado, es un cliente antiguo de la institución, es muy responsable y puntual en el pago de cuotas, se dedica al servicio de transporte, tiene su movilidad propia con la que trabaja como radiotaxi, vive en su casita ubicada en la zona de San Isidro Bajo, con su esposa que se dedica a las labores de la casa; sus hijos ya son independientes y viven también por la zona, el solo mantiene el hogar, trabaja solo para mantenerse el y a su esposa, El crédito será invertido en la compra de cuatro llantas y motor de arranque para su movilidad, al cliente le gusta tener su movilidad siempre en buen estado para poder trabajar sin problemas y brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes, esta muy agradecido con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Alfonso is married and is a long-time client of this institution. He is very responsible and punctual in making his payments. He works in transportation services; he has his own car that he operates as a radio taxi. He lives in a little house in the San Isidro Bajo area with his wife, who takes care of the housework. Their children are already grown, and they live in the same area. He works to be able to keep his home and to provide for his wife and himself. This loan will be invested in buying four tires and a starter motor for his car. His clients like that he always has his car in good working order and without any problems so as to provide the best service possible. He is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for having the confidence in him to grant him this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Merchlewitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of tires and starter motor for his car

loans.name: Yarely

texts.es:
Yarely C. R., vive en  el barrio Villa Sol de Soledad, ella tiene 3 hijos entre 10 y 16 años de edad; antes trabajaba en una empresa y simultáneamente se dedicaba al comercio, pero como trabajaba en el área de preparación de alimentos, su salud empezó a deteriorarse y en la actualidad tiene un trabajo independiente: se dedica a vender mercancías como cosméticos, artículos de cocina, accesorios y prendas de plata, mediante revistas especializadas y también tiene un pequeño punto de ventas   ubicado donde en la casa de su madrina quien la ayuda mucho. 

Inició su negocio hace 4 años cuando una amiga la incorporó al programa de una revista,  ahora ella muestra los productos que ofrece mediante este sistema de promoción y selecciona solo a clientes que tengan capacidad de pago para no perder dinero. Dice que para sacar a sus hijos adelante ella debe hacer todos los esfuerzos necesarios para hacer crecer su negocio, aunque recibe un gran respaldo de su  cónyuge a nivel  económico y emocional, esto la hace sentirse tranquila.

En la actualidad solicita  a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo un crédito por valor de $2.000.000 para comprar artículos que tiene encargados como fantasías, cosméticos y perfumes, desde hace dos años está con los programas de esta organización  y ella dice que con este dinero ha podido aumentar su capital, invertir en el levante de muros de su vivienda  y   le ha servido de mucho  porque pudo salirse de un empleo que le estaba haciendo daño a su salud y trabajar de manera independiente;  también considera que con ellos puede tener dinero disponible para buenos clientes que no tienen para comprar de contado y ella los financia y aprovecha las ofertas que traen los productos exhibidos en las revistas.
Su sueño es terminar de construir su casa que ya está muy avanzada y ponerla mas habitable,  para pasarse con su familia porque en la actualidad vive en la casa de sus padres. Quiere que sus hijos se preparen y progresen y que aprovechen los esfuerzos que ella puede hacer ahora que tiene buena salud y juventud.
texts.en:
Yarely C. R. lives in the neighborhood of Villa Sol de Soledad. She has three children between the ages of 10 and 16. Yarely previously worked for a company and also had a side business preparing and selling food. However, her health began to deteriorate and now works as an independent sales representative offering products such as cosmetics, kitchenware, accessories, and silver jewelry through specialized catalogs. Yarely also manages a small store in the house of her godmother, who has provided her with much support.

Four years ago, Yarely started her business when a friend also joined the catalog program. She now shows her products through a promotional system and selects only those customers who have the ability to pay in order to avoid losing money. Yarely says she has been able to move her children forward and make all the necessary efforts to grow her business. She receives a great deal of financial and emotional support from her husband, who helps her to remain calm.

At the moment, she is requesting a loan from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo in the amount of 2,000,000 COP to purchase items from which she will receive commission such as costume jewelry, cosmetics, and perfumes. Yarely has participated in the FMSD programs for two years and says this loan will increase her capital so that she can begin investing in the construction of her house. She also says FMSD allowed her to get out of a job that was damaging to her health and work independently. In addition, she believes that the organization gives financial access to good clients like her who cannot afford to conduct business in cash but have opportunities to take advantage of sales promotions for products offered in the catalogs.

Her dream is to finish her house, which is in the advanced stages of construction, and make it more habitable. She hopes to spend time with her family because she currently lives at her parents’ house. Yarely wants her children to become prepared and take advantage of her efforts to create opportunities for them while they are healthy and young.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase costume jewelry, cosmetics, and perfumes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of corn and other products

loans.name: Tesoro Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Tesoro inicia su primer ciclo con 20 socias, este banco se formo con L. solidaridad D. otro Banco Comunal Llamado Llapanchik donD. sus socias invitaron a cada uno D. sus familiares, conocidos para formar este nuevo Banco Comunal.
Es el caso D. Yoriko que es hija D. L. secretaria del Banco Comunal Llapanchik, Yoriko es soltera, tiene 20 años y vive con su mama, su alegría y compañerismo hizo que L. nombraran presidenta D. su Banco Comunal y Yoriko se comprometió a conducir su Banco para que sea el mejor, Yoriko ya conocía del trabajo en Finca pues en muchas ocasiones acompaño a su mama al Banco Comunal.
Yoriko junto a su familia se dedican a L. panificación en un horno alquilado, elabora panes, galletas que luego reparte a las diferentes tiendas D. acuerdo a sus pedidos con L. ayuda D. su familia. Además Yuriko estudia en un instituto. Su préstamo será invertido en L. compra D. harina y azúcar.
Los sueños D. Yoriko es terminar sus estudios y ejercer su carrera, además D. tener un horno propio.
texts.en:
The Banco Comunal Tesoro (Treasure Communal Bank) began its first cycle with 20 members. This bank was formed with the assistance of another communal bank called the Banco Comunal Llapanchik (Llapanchik means “all of us” in Quechua), which invited family members and acquaintances to form this new communal bank. This is how Yoriko, the daughter of the secretary of Banco Comunal Llapanchik, became a member.

Yoriko is 20 years old and single. She lives with her mother. Her cheerfulness and team spirit caused her to be named president of her communal bank, and Yoriko has promised to make the bank better. Yoriko was already acquainted with Finca’s work because she accompanied her mother to communal bank meetings.

Yoriko, together with her family, is engaged in bread making in a rented oven. She makes breads and cookies that she then distributes with the help of her family to different shops according to their orders. In addition, Yoriko studies at a technical school..

Her loan will be invested in the purchase of flour and sugar. Yoriko dreams of finishing her studies and working at her career, as well as having her own oven.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of flour and sugar.

loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
Mirasol L. is a married woman who lives in Sitio Nasug-ong, Barangay Caradio-an, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband, Romeo, who is 49 years old, works as a driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.

Mirasol joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past sixteen loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, thus uplifting her family's standard of living.

This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, which she intends to use to buy stock for her general store so that she can continue to save for the future renovation of her house.

Mirasol L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.


 About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her general store

loans.name: Kholik

texts.en:
Kholik N. is 48 years old, married, and has 4 children. Thanks to his efforts to get ahead and his positive attitude in the community he is now a well known and appreciated merchant in his area. Previously Kholik had been a farm hand, working in the fields for different people, and with his hard work he was able to purchase land and cultivate vegetables such as potatoes, onions, carrots, etc. His wife sells his harvest at the market and during their activity in this kind of business his products have become very popular among the buyers. 

Now Kholik requests a loan so he will be better able to serve his customers and differentiate himself from the competition. He will use the loan for purchasing seeds, fertilizer, and cattle. He only wants to continue growing his business and to be able to improve the quality of life for his family. With your help Kholik can get ahead.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer, and cattle

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a single man who sells charcoal to earn a living.  He is a member of the Neema group in Faulu Kenya. He is an active member of the group because he attends their weekly meetings regularly and pays his dues well.  

He has requested a loan of 20,000 KES through the group. With the loan, he will add to his stock of charcoal. He hopes to invest in another business in the future, which will be selling gas cylinders.

loans.use: To add to his stock of charcoal

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
This is 28-year-old Sabina R.. She is married and has two children, ages 5 and 7. In 2004, she established her grocery store business. Working seven days a week and eight hours a day, she supoorts her family. She has already received and successfully repaid two loans from Patan BPW. She used her most recent loan to increase the inventory of her store. In the future, Sabina plans to expand the business. She thanks you for your support.

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer.  With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner microfinance institution, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates: BPW Partner Page. Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.use: To increase inventory of store

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary J. is a lady who is married to Mr. Michael Ochuka and they have adult children who are no longer living with them. Mary owns a tree nursery. She purchases, matures and then sells the trees to others so that they can plant them on their farms. She also offers advice on how to better care for the trees, to her clients. She has been doing this for the past 20 years and she takes home a profit of about KES 10,000 per month.

Mary has applied for her first loan with KADET LTD, which she will use to buy more baby trees and later sell to clients when the trees mature. She hopes to earn some profit, which she will use to purchase food for her family.

Her future hopes are to expand her business so that she is able to add on to the family's income and, thus, sustain her family.

loans.use: Purchasing more trees for her tree nursery.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Sam is a thirty-year-old man and very development-minded; he lives in a rented apartment in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is a teacher by profession but feels he should venture into an income-generating activity so as to increase avenues of income to sustain his family. He dreams of owning a residential house for his family. Sam intends to use the loan facility to buy iron sheets and cement for his commercial house construction.

loans.use: Buying iron sheets and cement for his commercial house construction.

loans.name: Estrella Escolastica

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Mujeres Unidas se reúne en la ciudadela San Alejo de la bellísima ciudad de Portoviejo capital manabita, conocida por las hermosas playas que recorren todas sus costas y que son muy visitadas por los turistas nacionales e internacionales.

La señora Estrella lleva en el Banco Comunal ya 11 años y está muy agradecida con é y con la fundación Espoir ya que gracias a ellos logro sacar adelante en los estudios a sus hijos.  Ella tiene 47 años de edad, está casada hace 24 años y tuvo tres hijos,  el ultimo vive con ella y esta estudiando Ing. Civil en la Universidad. Su esposo es albañil.

Ella es una señora muy luchadora y trabajadora ya que en  las mañanas trabaja en el hospital y en las noches tiene un pequeño puesto de venta de hamburguesas y papas fritas en su casa, trabaja desde las 18h00 hasta las 21h00 todos los días.

Este nuevo crédito lo va a emplear en comprar productos para su negocio y  materiales de estudio para su hijo, porque así como se ayudó con los créditos para sacar profesionales a sus otros hijos igual quiere hacer con el menor. 

Su sueño es que su hijo sea un gran Ing. Civil.
texts.en:
The “Mujeres Unidas”  (United Women)  communal bank meets in the San Alejo neighborhood in the beautiful city of Portoviejo, Manabí province capital, famous for the beautiful beaches along its coast that are popular with national and international tourists alike.

Estrella has been in the communal bank for 11 years already and is very grateful to it and to Fundación Espoir because thanks to them she has managed to educate her children.  She is 47 years old, married for 24 years and has three children.  Her youngest still lives with her and is studying to be a Civil Engineer at the university.  Her husband is a bricklayer.

She is a very hard working, tenacious woman who works mornings in the hospital and at night runs a small hamburger and fried potato stand in her house.  She works from 6pm until 9pm every day.

This new loan will be used to buy supplies for her business and school supplies for her son because just as loans helped her educate her other children she wants to do the same for the youngest.  Her dream is that her son becomes a great civil engineer.

loans.use: To buy meat, bread, mayonnaise, tomatoes, etc. and for school supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand her husband's bakery business

loans.name: Clara

texts.en:
Clara C. is from the village of Binakalan, Gingoog City. She is 49 years old. Clara is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Clara owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, junk food, instant noodles, and canned goods in the local community. Clara has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Clara joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clara has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Clara is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Clara from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine L. lives in the Busega neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has five children, four of whom are in school.  Catherine has a business of food vending. She has been in this business for 20 years and she works seven days out of every week. Catherine sells her products in a shop on a retail basis.    

Catherine has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO. She will use it to buy more bags of cassava and sweet potatoes and bunches of bananas. She also generates additional income through selling charcoal. 

The main business challenges for Catherine include transport and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling on a wholesale basis only and to educate her children up to university. 

Catherine lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sweet potatoes and cassava and bunches of bananas

loans.name: Channtho

texts.en:
Mrs. Channtho S. (pictured above), 40, is a widow with three sons. Two of them are in school and another one assists his mother in the business. The family lives along national road number one about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Channtho has been selling vegetables for ten years. She buys them from the fellow villagers under contract before harvest season and transports them to sell in Phnom Penh market. She is requesting her first loan of $600 to purchase additional vegetables for resale.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables under contract for resale.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith G. is from the village of San Roque, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 35 years old. Judith is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Judith owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling snacks and other delicacies from yellow bananas, like banana cues and banana cakes, in the local community. Judith has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Judith joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Judith has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Judith is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed like ripe bananas and flour. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Judith from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients like ripe bananas & flour.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy additional DVD and VCD dics to sell.

loans.name: Heang

texts.en:
Heang T. is a 42-year-old married woman.  She lives in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Cham Province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents and uses this land to grow different kinds of crops. She plants rice and vegetable crops every year, and her crops are growing well because she has many years of experience in this sector. 

Presently, Heang T. wants to do dry-season rice farming and to grow vegetable crops on her farmland, but she does not have enough funds. For this reason, she is asking for a loan from Kiva. 

Heang T.'s husband is a construction worker.  She has four children, one of whom is married and three are single.

loans.use: To do dry-season rice farming and grow vegetable crop

loans.name: Zahida

texts.ru:
Zahida M. rodilas v 1954 qodu. Ona zamujem i imeyet 3 detey. Zahida, yeyo lubimiy muj i deti jivut v Absheron regione uje bolshe 15 let. Zahida uje 10 let kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom, ona u sebya doma izqotavlivayet nashi nacionalniye bludo "D0vga", "Dogramadj", "Ayran" , "Atlama" i prodayot ix v magazini v odnarazovix  posudax.
Zahida seychas nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit produkti dlya izqotovleniya etix blud.
texts.en: Zahida M. was born in 1954. She's married and has three children; they have lived in the Absheron region for over fifteen years. Zahida is a cook. She makes ethnic dishes such as "Dovga", "Dogramadj", "Ayran" and "Atlama" at home and then sells them to various stores. She's worked like this for ten years and is asking for a loan now, in order to purchase the necessary ingredients for these dishes.

loans.use: To buy ingredients

loans.name: Anatalia

texts.en:
Anatalia N. is from the village of Brgy. Bone North, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 32 years old. Anatalia is single. 

To make a living, Anatalia prepares and sells cooked food for daily meals. Anatalia has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Anatalia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Anatalia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Anatalia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products

location.town: Brgy. Bone North, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Miguel

texts.es:
Miguel B. R. un señor de 55 años de edad, esta casado con la señora Rosalina Jimenez Ruiz; pertenece a la poblacion del Paso de la Reyna Oaxaca, tiene 4 hijos de las respectivas edades: 36, 34, 27 y 25 años de los cuales los 3 primeros estan casados y el ultimo esta soltero. Su hijo el mas pequeño esta enfermo de sus piernas no puede caminar debido a un enfermmedad que le surgio desde pequeño.
El señor Miguel solicito el prestamo para comprar cerdos, ya que el tiene una Carniceria, en donde vende los cerdos destazados en diferentes productos como son: chicharron, biuches, chorizo, entre otros.
Es un señor muy trabajador, desde pequeño empezo a trabajar en diferentes oficios ya que el tan solo estudio la primaria porque fue el grado de estudio que sus padres le pudieron dar. La carniceria que actualmente tiene se lo dio su papa hace 5 años y dia con dia lo atiende para poder aumentar sus ingresos.
Su meta es poner otras carnicerias para poder generar empleos en su poblacion ya que es pequeña y casi no hay empleos.
texts.en:
Miguel B. R., who is 55 years old, is married to Rosalina Jimenez Ruiz. He lives in the village of Paso de la Reyna in Oaxaca, and has 4 children who are 36, 34, 27, and 25 years old. The first 3 are married and the last is single. His youngest son cannot walk due to an illness he suffered when he was small. 

Miguel requests the loan in order to purchase pigs, since he has a butcher's shop, where he sells pigs made into different products such as chicharron, biuches, chorizo, and others. 

He is a very hardworking man, who began to work at different jobs when he was young since he only studied through primary school because that was as much schooling as his parents were able to give him. The butcher's shop that he has now was given to him by his dad 5 years ago, and day by day he works there to increase his income. 

His goal is to have additional butcher's shops and be able to create jobs in his community since it is small and there are almost no jobs.

loans.use: Purchase pigs to sell

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en: Rukia is a 36-year-old widow and a mother of four children living in her house in Hioma, Uganda. Her family goal is to pay fees for her children to attain a degree as a minimum qualification. For 6 years she has been operating a retail shop. The business is at its boom-stage despite challenges in price fluctuations. Rukia needs the loan to buy sugar and fresh foods to sell.

loans.use: to buy sugar and fresh foods to sell

loans.name: Jean Marie Vianney

texts.fr: Jean Marie Vianney M. est agriculteur de légumineuses, et client d’ACB depuis 2008.  Il est marie, il 5 enfants entre 11 ans et 4 mois, trois d ses enfants vont à l’école, il est  né au Rwanda, et Jean Marie a fini ses études de 6 ans primaire.  Il va utiliser son prêt pour paiement de main d’œuvres et achat de semences, alors il augmenter la récolte qui est aussi sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire (agriculture).  Il voudrait être éleveur  d’une vache moderne, et pour la vie, il voudrait occuper sa famille, construire une maison pour eux, et aussi éduquer ses enfants jusqu’au niveau universitaire.
texts.en:
Jean Marie Vianney M. is a pulses grower, and client of ACB since 2008. He is married with five children ranging in age from 4 months to 11 years old. Three of them go to school. Jean Marie was born in Rwanda, and he completed six years of primary school. 

He will use his loan to pay for labor and to purchase seeds, which will help increase his crop. This is Jean Marie’s business growth strategy. In the future, he would like to become a modern cow breeder. In the long term, he wants to take care of his family, build a house for them, and provide his children with a university level education.

loans.use: to buy seeds and pay for labor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Bashiraan's Group

texts.en:
Bashiraan is very supportive by nature. She's always ready to help her family in their time of need. She operates a clothes-selling business for her community clients to help her family financially. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her clothes-selling business. She operates her business from her home. Through the loan, she will buy clothes in bulk quantity which will not only allow her to offer more variety to her clients but also minimize her cost of travelling as a result of bulk purchasing. 

She has given birth to two sons. Both of them left their education after matriculation and started doing jobs to support the family financially. 

Bashiraan is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In previous loan year, she established a good credit record and never missed any meeting. She belongs to Arifwala which is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan and known for its dairy industry.  She has been living there for the past 21 years. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Bashiraan.

loans.use: To buy clothes for clothes selling business.

loans.name: Avelita

texts.en:
Avelita V., from the village of D ban Calamba Misamis Occidental, is 46 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Avelita owns and operates a specialized retail store selling manufactured native products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 12 years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Avelita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 12,000 PHP from GDMPC that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is requesting her eighth loan of 12000 PHP to purchase more native products to sell. Avelita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional native products to sell.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul has practised potato farming in Olkalou for the last 11 years. He is 47 years old, married to Lydia and they have 4 school-going children.  

Paul was introduced to KADET by one of his friends and this will be his first loan. He plans to use it to buy potato seeds and fertilizer for planting and to do top dressing. In the future, Paul hopes to practise large scale farming and to start dairy farming on his farm

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer and to do top dressing.

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda is 41 years old and married with three children.

Nilda works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell in her sari-sari store.

Nilda has borrowed and paid back five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 10 years and earns additional income from pig fattening and fishing.

Nilda aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
This is Vilma, age 38, a resident of Pasay, Philippines.  She is married to Hacer, a Supervisor.  She has four children.  She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business.

Vilma operates a variety store. In the Philippines.  A variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood.  It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg.  Vilma earns it by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece.  She also sells personal products via direct selling.  Her store is adjacent to her house.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 900 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 45,000 loan.  She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.  She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Vilma hopes to be able to expand her store to other communities.  She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items needed in her variety store

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is 58 years old, married, and has five children. Rita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a variety store in the Philippines. She has requested a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more inventory to sell and computer supplies.

Rita has borrowed and paid eleven loans from NWTF prior to this loan. She has been running the variety store for 40 years. She also earns an income from an internet cafe.

Rita aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory to sell and computer supplies

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Mrs. Ven is a 30-year-old married woman. She now lives in Prey Chor district. Mrs. Ven and her husband have done most of their business as local farmers. They can earn $2.50 per day to use for the family expenses. They have two single children who are still learning in school. Mrs. Ven is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers and to pay for the plowing costs she hired.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pay for plowing costs.

loans.name: Abla Angèle

texts.fr:
Abla est une femme âgée de 44 ans. Elle est mariée à un agent commissionnaire de loto-sport.Elle a un enfant.
Abla travaille comme tresseuse et revendeuse de « sodabi « et de Louga (des bonbons faits à base d’arachides et de sucre)depuis 1998.Elle achète dans les fermes et dans les marchés de la place et revend à Avépozo .
Abla a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin de renforcer son commerce de SODABI.
texts.en: Abla is 44 years old and the mother of one child. Her husband is an agent of the football pools "Loto Sport". Abla has earned her living since 2009 by plaiting, and selling sodabi (a local alcoholic drink) and louga (candy produced from groundnuts and sugar). She buys her supplies from local farms and at neighboring markets, and resells her goods in Avépozo. Abla came to the microfinance institution WAGES and applied for her first loan to boost her sodabi business.

loans.use: to buy sodabi.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.es: Juliana, D. 48 años, es una mujer trabajadora, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo Sergio D. 47 años y sus 04 queridos hijos, a quienes desea brindar una mejor calidad D. vida.
